awd_titl_txt: Phase I I/UCRC University of Louisville Site: Center for Efficient Vehicles and Sustainable Transportation Systems (EV-STS)
awd_abstract_narration:
Phase I I/UCRC University of Louisville Site: Center for Efficient Vehicles and Sustainable Transportation Systems (EV-STS)

The University of Louisville (UL) will help establish and operate a multi-institution Industry/University Cooperative Research Center (I/UCRC) for Efficient Vehicles and Sustainable Transportation Systems (EV-STS) as one of two charter sites (Arizona State University will host the second charter site). Such a center is needed to support the U.S. automotive/ground transportation industry?s efforts to meet demanding new federal regulations governing vehicle fuel economy and emissions, as well as society?s expectations for improved sustainability in economic and personal activities. The EV-STS center will engage the industry?s critical stakeholders - vehicle manufacturers, component and system suppliers, fleet operators, ground transportation industry infrastructure providers, and state and local governments - in identifying important efficiency/sustainability related problems, and formulating a research program that develops innovative solutions.

The mission of the EV-STS center and its UL site is to leverage collaborations among corporate, government, and academic partners to conduct and disseminate industry-relevant research on technologies and tools that facilitate the design, manufacture, deployment, and operation of energy efficient, environmentally sustainable ground vehicles. The scope of this mission includes passenger cars, light- and heavy duty trucks, and motorized off-road equipment. It encompasses both vehicle-level technologies, and the infrastructure and transportation systems that incorporate ground vehicles. The mission is divided into four primary thrust areas: powertrains for full-electric vehicles and the entire continuum of electric-hybrid powertrains, including batteries, electric machines, power electronics, thermal management, packaging, etc., advanced internal combustion engines and alternative fuels, non-powertrain vehicle systems, and ground transportation systems and infrastructure. Within EV-STS the UL site will have a research focus on realizing sustainable ground vehicles. Site-specific topic areas are likely to include advanced batteries for use in electrified vehicles, lightweight structures, high performance computing tools for vehicle architecture optimization, emission and greenhouse gas reduction in internal combustion engines, and frictional loss management.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The University of Louisville's National Science Foundation Industry/University Cooperative Research Center (IUCRC) for Efficient Vehicles and Sustainable Transportation Systems (EV-STS) successfully developed, tested, and implemented innovative technologies aimed at significantly enhancing the energy efficiency and environmental sustainability of ground transportation vehicles. This encompassed various vehicle types, from passenger cars to heavy-duty trucks, as well as motorized off-road equipment. The efforts addressed both vehicle-level technologies and transportation system infrastructure, recognizing the complex and global nature of the automotive and ground transportation industries.

The center executed a series of successful projects across five key areas:


High Energy Density and Durable Battery System for Electric Vehicles: This involved creating a Li-S full cell with a unique pre-lithiated anode, resulting in a mesoporous coated Li-S cathode with a specific capacity of 900 mAh/g after 100 cycles. The incorporation of α-MoO3 as an anode material demonstrated promising alternatives to Si and Sn in Li-S batteries, offering enhanced performance and stability.

•    Advanced Fuel Injection Model: UL devised an innovative fuel injection model employing the state-of-the-art moment of fluid method, capable of handling multiple phases (solid, liquid, gas) and high-density ratios. The approach also integrated a highly efficient adaptive mesh refinement method to enhance computational efficiency.
•    Optimal EV Charging Station Location and Allocation Model: UL developed a model that utilized forecasted charging demand to determine the strategic location and capacities of EV charging stations. This design aimed to maximize convenience for electrified vehicle users in accessing public charging infrastructure.
•    Interchange Control System for Connected, Autonomous Vehicles (CAVs): The project created an interchange control system that efficiently manages CAVs at interchanges, enhancing efficiency and sustainability. This was achieved through the development of a reservation-based control system, Next-generation Interchange Control (NIC), which employed an agent-based centralized control strategy utilizing autonomous vehicles and vehicle-to-infrastructure (V2I) communication. NIC effectively resolved conflicts between individual vehicles, optimizing interchange capacity while minimizing delays and energy consumption.
•    Smart Sensor for Battery Health and Safety Monitoring: UL engineered a smart sensor to monitor the health and safety of hybrid/electric vehicle batteries. This innovation led to the development and demonstration of sensors capable of detecting gaseous byproducts of degraded or over-charged batteries, thereby improving reliability and safety. These sensors enabled significant gains in efficiency and diagnostic controls, preventing the lithium-ion battery from entering conditions that would lead to performance loss or catastrophic failure.
Thus far, the project has yielded thirteen peer-reviewed publications, with additional papers in progress. All projects at the UL Site actively contributed to the six primary goals of the EVSTS Center, and its broader impact agenda, including full inclusion in STEM fields, improved STEM education, a diverse and globally competitive STEM workforce, robust partnerships across academia and industry in the automotive and ground transportation sector, enhanced national security, increased U.S. economic competitiveness, and improved infrastructure for research and education.


Last Modified: 10/02/2023
Modified by: Sam Park
